Gram-Schmidt Processes

Thm 8.19: Let be a subspace with basis }. is defined as: (The pattern here is that the row defining the th vector uses the original basis vector on that row only. The vertical columns are unique to each orthogonal vector, that is to say, column 1 is always nothing, column 2 is , and column k is you're recursively defining the next vector)

Intuition: The basis vectors of are already linearly independent, so you know that none of them are parallel to the others. We start off with the first basis vector of becoming the first orthogonal basis vector . We can find a basis vector orthogonal to that by taking the second basis vector, and subtracting off it's projection onto the previous vector to define the new orthogonal basis vector (because we know that difference will be orthogonal) . We can keep going for all the basis vectors, such that , then not only are the vectors defining the same subspace, but they also are orthogonal to each other.

Definition: A set of vectors is orthonormal IF the set is orthogonal AND for
